author: ElectronicJunkie

title: Hollow throwaway pillar to aid printing thin towers

description.text:
This is a throwaway pillar that you can add to your printing plate to move the nozzle away between each layer in order to allow the top layer of your object to cool down. This is useful when your print fan does not cool your part down sufficiently, and you can't slow down your print speed any further.  
Some people use layer change G-codes for this, but if you're lazy to figure out what your layer change G-code ought to be, or your slicer doesn't support arbitrary layer change G-code, then use this object. I've included the scad file so you can change the pillar height to whatever you need it to be.  
The pillar is made wide and hollow to save material and increase its rigidity and footprint to avoid getting torn off the plate by nozzle friction. At its current size (70mm tall, and 10mm outer diameter), it consumes 1.0cm3 of material.

• Plate your model.
  • Get the print dimensions out of your slicer, specifically the height.
  • Set height in pillar.scad to the height you got from the previous step.
  • Export to STL.
  • Add to your printing plate.
  • Export G-code.
    • If your pillar gets knocked over during print, try increasing base_r, which increases the size of the brim. If that still doesn't work, increase pillar_r as well, until you can get it to stick for the entirety of your print.

title: A Better Filament Swatch for Designers

description.text:
"Better" for picking material for vases. :)  
Test & catalog your material with this sample swatch for designers.   
Inspired by graphic designer color swatch books, these sample prints can be collected loosely on a keychain ring or binded together as a "book" with an 8-32 nut & bolt.  
These models are specially designed to demonstrate how the material looks at different stepped thicknesses: .05mm, 1mm, 1.5mm, and 2mm.

Buy material. Print swatch. Carry swatches with you when you buy more material in person. Never accidentally buy the same shade of teal again.  
IMAGINE THE SAVINGS.

title: Peristaltic pump for single 28BYJ-48 stepper motor.

description.text:
WARNING: I have made significant imporments to this pump. Found here http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:803035 Simple pump and casing for stepper driver. Designed as a drip pump for adjusting PH in hydroponic system. Good thing because all it can manage is a drip. I'm using a 5v 28BYJ-48, the ULN2003 driver board that it came with and powering it through an arduino. (http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B0089JV2OM/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o09_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1). I designed the pump around 1/16" I.D. x 1/8" O.D. Silicone Tubing (http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00G9C9H20/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o03_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1). You will also need three 608 bearings,Two 6-8mm m3 bolts & nuts to attach motor, two m3 28mm bolts & nuts, glue to attach the rotorCap and a microcontroller. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=QFyGmHhftvQ 2/17/15
BaseV2 - Bolt pattern for driver board mounting fixed and holes for routing wires through bottom of base instead of out the side. Also added a vented version.
RotorcaseV2 - added holes and reliefs to shed any water trapped in case. Slight decrease in inner diameter to prevent back flow.

description.text: Box for basic scenography.
Printend in UP PLUS!2

This is my wireless printing add-on for my awesome Ultimaker. With it I can print wireless via bluetooth. The range is about 5 to 7 meters, but if the distance gets longer, the signal gets crapy'er and the speed of printing suffers. This add-on can be used with any 3D printer, if the printer uses serial communication. The module I used is this one: http://www.mdfly.com/index.php?main_page=product_info&products_id=63 If you do not want to have to make the PCB you can buy the break-out board as well:
http://www.mdfly.com/index.php?main_page=product_info&products_id=428&zenid=bka7i29d1id7h20ki7iop64ov7 Here's a movie the thing:
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=oXpfKqx7Uhc I also made a version which includes a LCD screen, that version is more dedicated for the Ultimaker electronics V1. For more info check out my blog at: http://jjshortcut.wordpress.com/2011/02/19/wireless-serial-bluetooth-module/

• Buy the bluetooth module (check ebay)
  • Make the PCB, etch or mill it or whatever your technique is
  • Solder all together
  • Program the bluetooth module (in AT mode)
  • Remove unused usb cables
  • Connect 5V,GND,TXD,RXD
  • Connect bluetooth module to computer with bluetooth dongle and make bluetooth COM port
  • PRINT WIRELESS!

Smartrap kartezyen yazici STL dosyalar?.

See 1:1 scale at http://www.eddiem.com/house
A possible layout for a kit barn based house. It is loosely based on
https://www.sheds.com.au/steel-kit-homes/country-home/
but with a custom floor plan and an extra 3M in length.
I will also be looking at an alternative barn which has an extra metre in width on the top floor - this makes a big difference. The site I have in mind is off-grid and is near a wetland so it has constrants others don't have.
The sunward (north) roofs are for solar panel so there should be no shadows over them. The composting toilet is away from the panels and the wet-lands. The upper bathroom is near the composting toilet so a low-flush toilet could be fitted. The upper floor is for living and the lower for workshops and parking - expect for toilet and laundry.

The design is 3D printable at 1% scale.
The main house is split into five parts for printing.
.4 nozzle works better than .6
The thinest walls are removable support.
I have not printed the roofs.

title: Dr Boo's Bowden Conversion of Jonas's Greg's Wade

description.text: I've been asked to upload this minor modification to the great wade extruder linked herein. What I've done is put an island on the 'top' (which when the item is placed upside down is now the bottom) that allows a screw-in push-fit connector to be placed for guiding the filament 'down' and attachment of PTFE tube to the extruder. I have also made a 'plate' which allows another push-fit connector to guide the filament from the top into the extruder, and allow attachment of the extruder base (now the top!) to the frame of a 1515 openbeam type frame. The tilting screws fit nicely around the new 'island', but you will need to manually cut off the tongue part of the pivoting mechanism which previously pushed against the filament. It's no longer needed, and I haven't bothered to edit the STL.

Print the STL which gives you the major parts of the extruder body. You will NEED to print this with support, as I have had to put in overhang for the push-fit island.  Cut off the 'tongue' of the pivoting part which pushes the filament; this no longer fits, as the 'island' is in the way.  glue/screw push-fit connector into the island, for feeding filament. Also, attach PTFE tube to the push-fit.  There is a base-plate which converts from the current 'base' to allow attachment of a 2nd push-fit, and screw to 1515 beam; this will follow ASAP.

description.header: Everybody loves minions. Now minions can love you back :)
description.text:
This is a simple design of a minion holding a heart (and my first upload to thingiverse so I hope everything works :P).
You can either just print it the way it is, or add a custom name/text in front of the heart.
If you want to customize the text on top of the heart you have two options:

description.header: 1: For this you'll need to have access to 3ds Max
description.text:
• Open "minion_heart.max"
  • Expand the node "MinionCombined" in the Scene Explorer
  • Selecte the node "name" in the Scene Explorer
  • Go to the "Modify" tab, select the "Text" modifier and change the Text attribute
    • *In order to avoid 3ds max recalculating the model after each letter you can tick the "Manual Update" option, change the Text and the hit "Update"

description.header: 2: For this Method you'll need a scad tool (e.g. OpenSCAD)
description.text:
Furthermore you need the "write.scad" file (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:16193) and the files "minion_heart.scad" and "minion_heart_base.stl"
  • Put the "write.scad" file, and the font you want to use (e.g. "knewave.dxf") in a subdirectory of the directory where you put the minion files, and call the subdirectory "write"
  • Open "minion_heart.scad"
  • Change the parameters of the write command
  • Hit F6
  • Export to STL
    • I printed the Minion in 33% size, with a 0.4mm nozzle and 0.25mm layer height.
    It's probably best to print it on its back, with supports for the feet, and probably also for the first couple of layers of the body, but I have printed it successfully without supports as well.

description.text: This is a basic AR-15 magazine follower. It fits any USGI magazine. NOTE.... This is NOT currently an anti-tilt follower and this is a work in progress. I am implementing anti-tilt functions that will be in the next revision, plus a few other changes to make it "beefy" and a magazine spring catch. The current one feeds and functions well, I put 100 rounds down range with it, no jams.... YET. Also in the works, is a whole printable magazine and spring.

1) You Have a need for an AR-15 Follower :) For example yours is busted on your last magazine and there are zombies outside of the door.
2) In a case with Zombies, make sure you can hold them at bay for approximately 30 minutes for printing +5-10 minutes for cleaning and sanding. Perhaps some pieces of wood nailed to the windows and doors would do the trick? 
3) Download the STL ... if Zombies have not destroyed the needed infrastructure.
4) PRINT AND HOLD OFF THOSE ZOMBIES!!!
5) After the print is successful, clean with some 150 grit sandpaper and finish with some 400-600 grit sandpaper. Make sure it is smooth and any hanging plastic is taken care of. We wouldn't want any round feeding malfunctions while battling Zombies? 
6) Install into a USGI magazine and load her up. By now, those boarded up windows and doors may have been compromised.... but now you can defend yourself against those Zombies with your AR-15.

Should the thingiverse community discourage weapons related items from being posted? My thoughts are that we all have different interests that can relate to the home production of items related to those same interests. What I would not like to see is some kind of censorship with regards to what an individual sees as "offensive". I agree with some others that ranking something low just because of political beliefs is not in the spirit of this community. To me, items should be ranked by the quality of execution. Since I have yet to study the particulars, let alone print this part, I will not rate this item.

This is my first multicopter design, inspired by a DJI 550.
The wingspan is 580mm and is compatible with props up to 10". My setup has 2212 sized DJI 920kv motors and 30A Mystery -SimonK ESC. Ardupilot system APM 2.6,ext GPS+compass, telemetry.
GoPro+ video transmitter. Im using 3300mAh 4s battery and has ~12-15min flight time atm.
But two new 5000mAh 4s is ordered such as new 9047 carbon props :) Print time: @90mm/s ~36h, PLA 210c / 50c heatbed. ~500g @ 30% infill. First test Video:
3300mAh, 8045 carbon props.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=NKppJZULv7Y
"Night-flight" leds: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=dHxybphx4TY This is a on going project and i will upload new files along progress is made. Future work:
LEDs, gimbal, latger battery bank, 9" props. I am not the designer of the gimbal/motors/antenna/props or the gopro.

title: Hobby Zone Super Cub Motor Mount

description.text:
This is an adapter to allow you to mount an outrunner to the brushed motor mount that came with the plane. The X portion allows just about any outrunner to be used that mounts with a X mount. The replacement motor that will be used is a Common Sense RC E5-M-14.  
Designed using DesignSpark Mechanical. The design was completed in 3 hours which included downloading the software, installing it, watching a couple of tutorial videos and then designing the part.

Printed with PLA. .1mm layers 100% infill.   
Use self tapping (sheet metal) screws to attach the motor. Socket head screws are best.  
Be careful when drilling the motor mount holes in the PLA. Size the drill bit to the shank of the self tapping screw so that only the threads engage into the plastic. Advance the drill into the PLA about 1/16 (2mm) at a time. Otherwise the drill bit can melt the plastic and then become a permanent part of the motor mount !

remixed_from.author: peddiparth
remixed_from.title: Coil Jig for different rod sizes

title: Coil Jig for different rod sizes V2

description.text:
This is a coil Jig design enhancement. You can create coils of Kanthal or Nickle wire easily with this jig. Insert a M3 machine screw in one of the holes for the wire guage size on one cylinder.
Insert the center smooth rod, and fix it with grub screw on the other cylinder.
Insert wire thru the hole opening next to the rod. Hold the end of wire (that comes out of the cylinder) with your thumb, and rotate it once around the center smooth rod to start the coil.
Insert the protruding center smooth rod thru the center axial hole in the second cylinder, and start rotating it to make a coil.
The machine screw will keep the wire in place while rotating so that you will make a good coil easily. The angles are marked on the cylinder in case you are coiling a stiff wire. (0deg, 90deg, 180deg,270deg). If you start at 0deg reference mark, it will be your reference to end your coil at 0deg or 180deg reference marks. Twist it 90degrees more than the end point in case of a stiff wire. The screw holes for the machine screw are not threaded, so they may require some force to get the screws in the first time. They are configured so that the machine screw will press the coil to the center rod for the selected guage wire hole. I added the left side hole for Left Hand (clockwise) coils as an enhancement from the previous design. I also increased the wire hole for better prints. NOTE: I am yet to print and test this design out. You are welcome to try and let me know if any fixes are required.

description.text:
Sega AstroCity Control Panel
Attention, c'est un WIP !!!!

This is meant to be incorporated in larger things.  Say you're printing a device enclosure and you want it to have an ethernet port, or you just want to use RJ-45 as a convenient 8 pin connector.  Add this to your design and you can use the modular RJ-45 jacks sold at hardware stores that are meant to clip into wall plates.
Updated: Tightened the opening to clip more securely, cleaned up the openscad code, and made the whole thing a module to more facilitate use in other designs.  Now jacks clip in so tightly that its hard to get them out again.
Print it and push a modular keystone jack into it until it's flush.

description.text:
Buste du Gundam 00 Raiser.
Remix of the marvelous work by MrGundam :)
Spécial Thanks to him !

  • 27/05/2015 :
    . Sanding : http://burogu.makotoworkshop.org/index.php?post/2015/05/26/BustGundam00Raiser03
    . Sommes photography added !

  • 22/03/2015 :
    . Sommes photography added !

  • 26/02/2015 :
    . impression du backpack Ok.
    . Travail terminé ! Enjoy !
    . Upload des 16 piéces séparées et numérotées.

  • 25/0292015 :
    . impression des épaules/pectoraux OK.

  • 19/02/2015 :
    . I have make somes hollow to save filament.
    . Impression de la tête OK, Mise à jour du fichier TeteOK.stl et TeteOK.skp
    . Impression du buste OK, Mise à jour du fichier BusteOK.stl et BusteOK.skp
    .Corrections de problèmes sur les épaules.
    .The other parts are tested printed yet !

To save time and filament, i use theses spécial print settings :
  • For all the parts, rezise at 75% (0,75) !

  • The parts A - B - C - E - G - H - I - K - L - M :
    layer height = 0,2 mm
    honeycomb = 20% (0,2)

  • The parts F - J :
    layer height = 0,2 mm
    honeycomb = 10% (0,1)
    Support enable

  • The parts O - P :
    layer height = 0,2 mm
    honeycomb = 10% (0,1)
    solid layer top = 4
    solid layer bottom = 4

  • The part N :
    layer height = 0,2 mm
    honeycomb = 15% (0,15)

  • The part D :
    layer height = 0,4 mm
    honeycomb = 10% (0,1)
    • This would use about 500 gr of filament !
    Use Grey filament for easy sanding work !

author: asder1206

title: Vise for Holding a PCB (or other lightweight items)

description.text: This thing is a vise that I made to hold a PCB while soldering.  It will also accomodate other light weight items.   The working space between the jaws is 100mm.   There are tabs on the jaws to allow the vise to be secured to a table (a little masking tape also works).

It requires a 5mm diameter threaded steel rod of about 200mm in length with two or three washers, two normal nuts, and a locking nut to match.   
Print the handle, left and right sides, and two backbones.   I printed with a layer of .36 and a fill of .25.  Assemble gluing the backbones into the left (stationary) side.   Locking nut in handle.  Two washers between handle and left jaw.  One washer (small one) and two nuts on other side of left jaw from handle with second nut locking the pair in place on the threaded rod.   Final nut on outside of right (moving) jaw in recess built for it.   The nuts that fit into recesses should stay put based on friction but if not use some epoxy!  
This is version two of what was originally uploaded.  There is now a recess in the left handle for the two locking bolts.   This allows the vise to close completely.   There is also a second handle now included.   This handle has a ball and joint feature that should allow the grip to rotate as it is turned.   This does require some degree of printer precision.   I would recommend printing it with a layer height of .3 or less.  You may have to use some amount of force, and a pair of pliers or visegrips, to break loose any adhesion.  
I print everything in PLA and was concerned that melting might be an issue but in practice, have so far (but without a lot of work yet), not found this to be the case.   If you have heated up the PCB enough to cause an issue with the PLA you are probably getting it too hot.   If this is an issue for you I would recommend printing in ABS.   An alternative might be to shield the jaws with some foil to disperse heat.

This air knife shoots a wide flat band of air (works well with coolant too!) and clamshells around modular coolant/air pipes commonly seen in shops.  Works really well, and is much quieter than a standard nozzle.

I build them vertically with the thin part at the top.  If you face them inside out (back to back), it will improve the surface finish on the inside where it counts (no retract fuzz).  
For version 1-1.0, One side needs to be tapped for 1/2" long 6-32 or similar screw X 4.  There is little bleed out the sides, but you can always use a very thin layer of silicone upon assembly.  
Nozzle 1.3 is universal (same for both sides).  It uses 4-40 x .5 screws and nuts.  It doesn't matter which side you assemble it from.  I also added a 1/4 inch hole for easy mounting.

comments.text:
• update*
    We finally got around to installing one for our flood coolant on our Mill, and it's great. The nice thing is you don't have to constantly adjust the nozzle between tool changes, because you can use it to spray a vertical stream for varying tool lengths.

author: Sanx

description.text: Makes taking anaglyphs really easy and using a stepper motor to drive the caddy means loads of control. Specifically designed for the Manfrotto quick release plate tripods and the Nikon D800 camera, but any similar or smaller camera will work as well. Bigger cameras may work, your milage may vary. How you control the camera and stepper motor are completely down to you. Similarly, if your camera falls off, that's also you :) NOTE The mount arms allow for about a 12cm maximum parallax when using the handle... that's more than humans, but if you're taking shots outside and viewing the final image from a bit further back it works well. You can always manually limit the travel. Just Added manfrotto 200pl extender.stl: for raising your pointy shooty or smaller camera up about 20mm to allow lenses to clear the rails.

For printing I'd recommend using as much density as your plastic/time budget  will allow 60% plus. For the mount plate I'd go to 100% purely because this attaches to the tripod and bears all the weight. If you have a couple grands worth of camera balanced on this thing you're going to want it strong.  
Designed to print at 0.2mm layer height with a 0.4mm nozzle.  
Also, all the parts friction fit for me, your milage may vary, but again, think of the camera... heavy duty glue will ease your peace of mind.  
All of the parts print without support and where required, support is built in and snaps right off. I'd recommend printing the drive bar in the stepper section with a raft, the teeth need to be clean in profile - that's a real mission without the raft.

You will need the following materials:
  • 1x mount plate print
  • 4x mount arm manual prints
  • 1x caddy plate print - the manual one has a handle
  • 4x caddy arm prints
  • optionally 4x caddy arm pin prints if you're wanting to glue the bearings in place
  • 4x bearings id: 10mm, od:30mm, w: 9mm (6200/2RS )
  • 2x Makerbeam lengths of 300mm (Technobots)

You will need the following materials:
  • 1x mount plate print (remove the support for the motor, the lugs on the side are for you to secure the motor with something elastically)
  • 4x mount arm stepper prints
  • 1x caddy plate print - the manual one has a handle, but works just as well
  • 1x drive bar print
  • 4x caddy arm prints
  • optionally 4x caddy arm pin prints if you're wanting to glue the bearings in place
  • 4x bearings id: 10mm, od:30mm, w: 9mm (6200/2RS )
  • 2x Makerbeam lengths of 300mm (Technobots)
  • 1x Stepper motor 42x42x33mm dimensions (Proto-pic)
  • 1x 3mm HTD pulley with 24 teeth (may need a bore reducer) (Motionco)
    • Assembly should e self explanatory, the tricky bit will be lining up the stepper and the drive bar. The bar is designed to fit as far forward as possible, see the screenshot in the gallery.

A modular case for the new Raspberry Pi 2 model B or the old Raspberry 1 model b+ (plus). Description:

Top Logo - This Top Part has a optional breakthrough for the 40 GPIO Pins and has a opened Raspberry Logo

Camera Module - this is a housing for the Raspberry camera and fits perfectly thru the "base breakthrough" Update: 03/08/2015
  • I've made the bottom and tops stronger
  • Added two another logo-tops
    -- Windows 10
    -- Windows on Raspberry (wraspi)

The pictures shows a print in black ABS (1.75 mm) Sliced with Slic3r 1.2.5 2 Perimeter 3 full Top/Bottom Layers 50% rectilinear infill 0.2 mm Layer height Perimeter Speed 60 mm/s Only the Raspberry Base needs some little bridging abilities (microSD Slot, micro USB Power) or you add some support. Printed on my custom style Delta with a 0.4 mm Hexagon Hotend.

Here's an old model phone that I made for a prop in our school's play. The gap at the connection in the original model (pictured) between the base and upper post has since been fixed and should fit together without problems.

Designed in Openscad. Sliced with Kisslicer. Printed without supports on all pieces, even the ear piece. The bridging over the inside of the ear piece actually ended up looking like a screen to hear from.   
I printed at .25 m layer height and 20% infill and everything came out well.   
If your machine doesn't bridge well or if you would like a smooth bottom on the ear piece enable supports however this will tend to support the rounded edges which should be able to print without them.

I am making these to 3D print them for my wedding in July. Each guest will receive their own word, similar to an intention. I wanted to show how a 3D printer is different from a mold in that each one can be unique. It was initially made with Tinkercad but I have since derived it to be made with openSCAD. In the zip file is everything to run OpenSCAD and make your own by changing the word variable. In addition, I have included all 190 or so STLs. that I made while determining the best parameters for inputting, rendering, and exporting and are my back-ups if I can't figure out how to make a batch file.. Limitations:
If someone knows how to create a batch file using the words in the text file, that would be amazing. I also haven't figured out how to get openscad to run via command line and successfully output an stl. Enjoy. and Peace!

title: OctoPi with TFT and Camera Case

description.text:
A case for an OctoPi using a Raspberry Pi model B+, a  TFT 2.8" screen from Adafruit (1601), and a Raspberry Pi camera  
Ready to print!

(1) Attach the lid to the base with superglue (the right way round!).
(2) Drill out the holes in the camera mount to 1.5mm. Put the mount in place in the base lining up with the square hole. A spot of glue may be required to attach the mount to the base.
(3) Start to insert the assembled OctoPi through the open end, Micro SD card first. Put the camera on the mount and attach with a couple of small screws,. (The top of the camera should be away from you when holding the box with the open end to your left.) Fold the camera cable and route it over the Micro SD card.
(4) There is a spacer to level the screen on the end of the PCB without TTH soldering, and another (optional) to put on top the Ethernet port, a third (necessary) then slips in on edge behind the power socket to fix the distance between the two PCBs.
(5) Push the OctoPi upwards and in so that the screen fits in the frame in the lid. This is easiest with the box upside down.
(6) Push in the support below the OctoPi (with the slots downwards) to hold it in place. The slots are to save material and allow ventilation.
